p.text: [Pt 46 insrt Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 7 July 2006]

row.entry: This Division deals with the general procedure for accounts and inquiries under judgments and orders.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Equity Division of the Supreme Court: General —Rules 46.10 –46.18

row.entry: This Division sets out the procedure for taking account in the equity division of the Supreme Court (other than proceedings in some of the specialist lists). It applies to judgments in proceedings for the administration of a deceased estate, the execution of a trust and the sale of property.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Equity Division of the Supreme Court: administration accounts and inquiries etc — Rules 46.19 – 46.28

row.entry: This Division applies to proceedings the Supreme Court in relation to the administration of a deceased estate and to proceedings for the administration of a trust.
The rules in this Part are based on the former SCR Pts 48 and 49. The rules are virtually identical with the former SCR Pts 48 and 49.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.1] r 46.1 Application of Part (cf SCR Part 49, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Application of Part (cf SCR Part 49, rule 1)

p.text: This Part applies to accounts, inquiries and other matters under an order in the same way as it applies to accounts, inquiries and other matters under a judgment.
In the application of this Part to accounts, inquiries and other matters under an order:
references in this Part to a judgment extend to an order, and
references in this Part to the giving of judgment extend to the making of an order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.2] r 46.2 Account: summary order (cf SCR Part 48, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Account: summary order (cf SCR Part 48, rule 1)

p.text: If a party claims an account or makes a claim which involves taking an account, the court may, on application by that party at any stage of the proceedings:
order that an account be taken, and
order that any amount certified on taking the account to be due to any party be paid to him or her.
The court may not make an order under subrule (1)(a) :
against a defendant who has not filed an appearance, unless he or she is in default of appearance, or
if it appears that there is some preliminary question to be determined.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.3] r 46.3 Account or inquiry at any stage (cf SCR Part 48, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Account or inquiry at any stage (cf SCR Part 48, rule 2)

p.text: The court may make orders for the taking of any account or the making of any inquiry.

This Part was derived from the previous English Orders 43 (pre-trial accounts) and 44 (accounts after final judgments and orders). This distinction is not maintained in the current NSW rules: Hagan v Waterhouse [1983] 2 NSWLR 395 at 398 . Orders for accounts to be taken before trial are limited to such accounts and inquiries as are necessary to determine the rights of the parties and which would otherwise be directed at the trial: Garnham v Skipper (1885) 29 Ch D 566 ; Rapid Metal Developments (Aust) Pty Ltd v Rosato [1971] Qd R 82 . Ordinarily, accounts should not be ordered until the plaintiff's right to such account has been admitted or established: Batthyany v Walford (1887) 36 Ch D 269 at 276–7 . A judgment need not set out reasons for holding that a party is in an accounting relationship with respect to a particular transaction: Sharpe v Goodhew (FCA, Drummond J, 11 December 1992, unreported, BC9203908).

All the affidavits in evidence before the judge may be used at the subsequent accounting or inquiry. The practice is for notice to be given which identifies the parts of the transcript and affidavit material that is to be relied upon. If it is desired to conduct any further cross-examination notice must be given: de Mora v Concha (1886) 32 Ch D 133 . Exhibits in evidence before the judge that are intended to be used in the taking of accounts are put in evidence again and remarked. Any new evidence to be adduced in the inquiry is taken in the same way as it would be in an ordinary hearing.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.4] r 46.4 Account: directions (cf SCR Part 48, rule 3)

p.text: If the court makes an order for the taking of an account, the court, by the same or a subsequent order:
may give directions concerning the manner of taking or vouching the account, and
without limiting paragraph (a) , may direct that in taking the account the relevant books of account are taken to be evidence of the matters contained in them.

A fiduciary may also be ordered to account for profits derived as a result of some specific instance of misconduct. The form of accounting will depend on the precise circumstances. Sometimes the accounting may be limited to a specific transaction. In other instances, the accounting may extend to the whole of the profits of a business created as a result of the fiduciaries' misconduct: Timber Engineering Co Pty Ltd v Anderson [1980] 2 NSWLR 488 . But the court retains an overriding discretion to direct the scope of the accounting according to the particular circumstances: Warman International Ltd v Dwyer (1995) 182 CLR 544; 128 ALR 201; [1995] HCA 18; BC9506414 .
Legislation cited in [46.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995.

Where the accounting party has kept appropriate financial records, they will often be admissible under the “business records” provisions of the Evidence Act 1995 . Aside from that basis of admissibility, it has been held that the books of account are admissible in partnership suits as prima facie evidence under the general law: Gething v Keighley (1878) 9 Ch D 547 at 551 . In other kinds of proceedings it may be necessary to obtain a specific direction in relation to the use to be made of the books of account: Cookes v Cookes (1863) 11 WR 871; 3 New Rep 97.
Legislation cited in [46.4.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 46.7.

The usual form of order is for the taking of accounts in common form, that is, “common accounts”. To obtain an order for common accounts, a plaintiff does not need to establish any particular misconduct by the defendant. The claim may be based either on the defendant’s general failure to provide a satisfactory accounting in the course of the administration of the estate or trust, or on a specific allegation of breach of duty, for example, neglect in relation to the proper administration of the relevant estate: Re Wrightson [1908] 1 Ch 789 (failure to acquire proper security). Where the claim for accounting is based on a specific allegation of breach of duty, it is generally not appropriate to seek to rely on other allegations of misconduct to seek to change the basis of the subsequent accounting: Re Wrightson, above; Gava v Grljusich [1999] WASC 13; BC9902403 ; Glazier Holdings Pty Ltd v Australian Men's Health Pty Ltd (No 2) [2001] NSWSC 6; BC200100163 at [56] . However, if the evidence, either at the initial hearing or in the course of the subsequent taking of accounts, establishes instances of wilful default, they may be taken into account: Re Youngs (1885) 30 Ch D 421 at 431–2 ; Re Symons (1882) 21 Ch D 757 ; Glazier Holdings Pty Ltd v Australian Men's Health Pty Ltd (No 2), aboveat [78], [82] [93]. The accounts must identify the property received, expenses incurred and the distribution of the surplus. The other parties to the accounting may then challenge the sufficiency and accuracy of the accounts by invoking the procedure permitted by r 46.7 .
Legislation cited in [46.4.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 15.3.

Accounts may also be ordered on the basis of wilful default. An order for the taking of accounts on the basis of wilful default should be specifically pleaded: Glazier Holdings Pty Ltd v Australian Men's Health Pty Ltd (No 2) [2001] NSWSC 6; BC200100163 at [91]–[94] ; Juul v Northey [2010] NSWCA 211; BC201006158 at [191], [204]–[206] (absence of specificity obscured the factual findings required to sustain the claim) see also UCPR r 15.3 . Such a claim requires a plaintiff to show that the accounting party has been guilty of at least one instance of misconduct that has led to the loss of property that would otherwise have been received or retained as part of the estate: Sleight v Lawson (1857) 3 K & J 292; 69 ER 1119 at 1121–2; Partington v Reynolds (1858) 4 Drew 253 at 255–6; 62 ER 98 at 98–9 ; Re Stevens [1898] 1 Ch 162 at 171 . Although the concept of “wilful default” is not confined to instances of deliberate wrongdoing: Bartlett v Barclays Bank Trust Co Ltd [1980] 1 Ch 515 at 546, mere delay in collecting property, or poor record keeping, even if it has caused additional expense, does not justify an order for accounting on the basis of wilful default: Re Stevens, above; Meehan v Glazier Holdings Pty Ltd (2002) 54 NSWLR 146; [2002] NSWCA 22; BC200200709 . But, even where some instance of proven misconduct has been established, the court retains a discretion to refuse an order for the taking of accounts on the basis of wilful default, and may do so unless it is satisfied that the conduct of the accounting party gives rise to a reasonable inference that there have been other instances of misconduct: Re Tebbs [1976] 2 All ER 858 at 863 ; Russell v Russell (1891) 17 VLR 729 . Where accounts are ordered on this basis, the accounting party must bring to account every instance of misconduct, whether or not it was specifically pleaded and established in the proceedings leading to the making of the orders: Bartlett v Barclays Bank Trust Co Ltd, above; Gava v Grljusich [1999] WASC 13; BC9902403 at [22] . The accounting party must account for both property actually received and also property that might have been received had it not been for the default. If an accounting on the basis of wilful default establishes that estate funds have been wrongly dealt with, the accounting party will be ordered to make appropriate restitution: Glazier Holdings Pty Ltd v Australian Men's Health Pty Ltd (No 2) [2001] NSWSC 6; BC200100163 .

This Part sets out the procedure which is to be followed in the taking of accounts however, it does not constitute an exhaustive code: Hagan v Waterhouse [1983] 2 NSWLR 395. In Iacullo v Iacullo [2012] NSWSC 189; BC201201198 orders were made by consent for the appointment of trustees in relation to a sale of property and that the trustees take accounts relating to the sale of the property. Thereafter each party challenged separate aspects of the trustee’s determination. Black J determined that the trustees determination should be treated as a referee’s report under UCPR Pt 20 Div 3, and that the principles that apply to the adoption of reports of that kind should also apply to the assessment of the trustees accounts.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.5] r 46.5 Account: form and verification (cf SCR Part 48, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Account: form and verification (cf SCR Part 48, rule 4)

p.text: The items on each side of an account must be numbered consecutively.
Unless the court otherwise orders, an accounting party must verify his or her account by affidavit and the account must be made an exhibit to the affidavit.

Before being cross-examined, the accounting party is entitled to notice of the points on which they are to be cross-examined: Lord v Lord (1866) LR 2 Eq 605. It is not sufficient to state that all the items but one are objected to: McArthur v Dudgeon (1872) LR 15 Eq 102; Glover v Ellison (1872) 20 WR 408.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.6] r 46.6 Account: filing and service (cf SCR Part 48, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Account: filing and service (cf SCR Part 48, rule 5)

p.text: Unless the court otherwise orders, an accounting party must file his or her account and verifying affidavit.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.7] r 46.7 Account: notice of charge or error (cf SCR Part 48, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Account: notice of charge or error (cf SCR Part 48, rule 6)

p.text: If a party seeks to charge an accounting party with an amount beyond that in respect of which the accounting party by his or her account admits receipt, he or she must give to the accounting party notice of the charge, stating, so far as he or she is able, the amount that he or she seeks to charge, with brief particulars.

If a party alleges that any item in the account of an accounting party is erroneous in amount or otherwise, he or she must give to the accounting party notice of the allegation, stating the grounds for alleging the error.
Legislation cited in [46.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 46.7(1), r 46.7(2).

The practice is to call the charge referred to in r 46.7(1) a surcharge and that referred to in r 46.7(2) a falsification. Both surcharges and falsifications may be based on matters of fact or law. Surcharges are usually dealt with first. The onus is on the surcharging party who begins. With falsifications, the onus is on the accounting party who accordingly begins: Pit v Cholmondeley (1754) 2 Ves Sen 565; 28 ER 360 ; Magafas v Carantinos [2009] NSWSC 1124; BC200909615 at [14] ff. No form of notice is prescribed in the UCPR but there is an appropriate form in precedent 3(11) in A G Nevill & A W Ashe, Equity Proceedings with Precedents (NSW), Butterworths, 1981 and Gray v BNY Trust Co of Aust Ltd [2009] NSWSC 789; BC200907418 at [14] ff.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 46.8] r 46.8 Account: allowances (cf SCR Part 48, rule 7)

p.text: In taking an account under a judgment, all just allowances must be made.

What are just allowances depends very much on the circumstances of the case and the matter is usually left to be decided on the taking of the accounts: Brown v de Tastet (1821) Jac 284 at 294 . See also Marriage of Elias (1977) 29 FLR 393 ; Apand Pty Ltd v Kettle Chip Co Pty Ltd (No 2) (1999) 88 FCR 568; 162 ALR 505; [1999] FCA 483; BC9901851 (allowance for overhead expenses).

An accounting party who is an agent who would normally charge commission he would normally be allowed something in respect of commission. See for example, Berwick v Lane (1899) 81 LT 722. Further, an executor will be allowed all reasonable expenses incurred in the conduct of his office.

If it appears to the court that there is delay in the prosecution of any account, inquiry or other matter under a judgment, the court may make such orders as it thinks fit for staying or expediting the proceedings or for the conduct of the proceedings.
An instance of undue delay in taking of accounts is provided by Re Cornish Tin Lands Ltd [1918] WN 377, where nothing happened for 3 years and the proceedings were stayed with costs.
